pageData.text: Microscopes allow scientists to observe cells and other details that are not visible to the naked eye. In this activity, you will learn about the parts of a microscope, stage movement, how to calculate total magnification of the microscope, basic care and handling of a microscope, and the importance of <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>depth of field</button>. The microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button> in this set have been selected to introduce the use of a microscope. During the activity you will look at prepared slides of the letter “e,” colored threads, cork, dust, a tick, and a mite. While viewing these slides, you will learn how to position and move slides on a microscope stage, focus on an object on a microscope slide, and handle and care for a microscope and microscope slides.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify the parts of a <button class='glossary-text'>compound light microscope</button> and their functions.
Distinguish between <button class='glossary-text'>stereomicroscopes</button> and compound light microscopes.
Demonstrate correct use of the microscope to focus on and view specimens.
Explain how the best image can be obtained from a microscope.
Calculate total magnification.
Describe proper handling and care for microscopes and microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button>.

pageData.text: The microscope has allowed for many advancements in science. Bacteria are very small and because they are so small, they have a high surface area to volume ratio. This allows them to readily take up as many nutrients as possible. It is widely believed that bacteria are so small that they can only be seen with the aid of a microscope. However, some bacteria are large enough to be seen with the naked eye.

In 1999, Heide Schulz was examining sediment cores from the ocean. The cores came from 300 feet below the waters near the Namibia's Skeleton Coast. In the samples, she noticed “pearl”-like organisms1. When she looked at these structures under a microscope, she discovered that they were not pearls, but rather giant bacteria. The researchers named the new microbe the “Sulfur pearl of Namibia,” Thiomargarita namibiensis. The cells are three-quarters of a millimeter in diameter, and they use sulfide and nitrate as their nutrient source. The sediment in the ocean is low in nutrients and only when occasional storms occur are nutrients stirred up and replenished. About 98% of T. namibiensis is a very large vacuole that it uses to store nitrogen so it can survive until the next storm comes. 1Wuethrich, B. (1999). Giant sulfur-eating microbe found. Science.
https://www.science.org/content/article/giant-sulfur-eating-microbe-found.

pageData.desc: A woman looking through a microscope.
pageData.altText: A woman looking through a microscope.

pageData.text: Scientists use microscopes to observe objects that are too small to be seen (or too small to be seen in detail) with the unaided eye. Microscopes have played a pivotal role in our understanding of plant and animal cells, crystals, and microorganisms. Two common types of microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>stereomicroscopes</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>compound light microscopes</button>. Both types manipulate light to create an enlarged image of an object.

Stereomicroscopes typically are used to view relatively large objects, such as fruit flies. They usually have a large <button class='glossary-text'>working distance</button>—the space between the lens and the specimen—which makes them ideal for use in dissections. For this reason, stereomicroscopes are often referred to as dissecting microscopes.

Compound microscopes are used to view even smaller objects. Objects viewed under a compound microscope are typically mounted on a microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>, a small, rectangular piece of glass, which is covered with a thin, protective piece of glass called a <button class='glossary-text'>coverslip</button>. A compound microscope has a much smaller working distance than a stereomicroscope.

Specimens intended for viewing with a compound light microscope are usually thin, and may also be chemically cleared. This allows light to pass through the specimen with a minimum amount of light scattering. The scattering of light rays results in a loss of <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> (the ability to distinguish between two adjacent objects). The lower the resolution of an image, the blurrier it appears.

Specimens are often stained with one or more dyes during the preparation of a microscope slide. Most specimens, especially after they have been preserved and processed into thin sections, have little, if any, color. This results in very little contrast when the specimen is viewed. Dyes add contrast for greater ease of viewing.

When a suitably-prepared specimen is viewed with a properly-adjusted microscope, the resulting image will not only be magnified, it will also have high resolution and good contrast. Thus, the microscope will reveal fine details that could not be detected by the unaided eye.

Operating a MicroscopeTo observe objects under a microscope, you must first become familiar with the parts of a microscope (Figure 1 and Table 1). The shape and location of the major parts of a microscope can vary, so if you have trouble locating a component on your microscope, consult the instructions that came with your instrument.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a monocular compound light microscope with its structures labeled.

tableData.text: Lens you look through; usually 10x powerA microscope with one ocular lens is monocular, and a microscope with two ocular lenses is binocular
tableData.hoverText: Lens you look through; usually 10x power A microscope with one ocular lens is monocular, and a microscope with two ocular lenses is binocular

tableData.text: Objective Lenses Scanning Low Power High (Dry) Power

Magnifies the specimen
Magnifies 4x the actual size
Magnifies 10x the actual size
Magnifies 40x the actual size
tableData.hoverText: Magnifies the specimen Magnifies 4x the actual size Magnifies 10x the actual size Magnifies 40x the actual size

tableData.text: Holds the microscope slide or specimen
Allows for controlled movement of the slide
Secures the slide on the stage
Condenses light from the light source into a narrow beam

Source of light (usually an electric-powered light bulb)
Used first to focus the specimen; not used for the high power objective lens
Used to make minor adjustments in focusing; only adjustment used with high power objective lens

pageData.text: Every microscope possesses at least one <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>, or ocular lens. Those with only a single eyepiece are known as <button class='glossary-text'>monocular</button> microscopes. Many compound microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>binocular</button> microscopes and have two eyepieces, which you look through with both eyes as you would with a pair of binoculars. The long cylinder extending from the eyepiece is called the <button class='glossary-text'>body tube</button>, or monocular tube. If there are two eyepieces and tubes, these are called binocular tubes. At the opposite end of the tube(s) are a series of magnifying <button class='glossary-text'>objectives</button>. Each objective magnifies objects to a different power. The lowest power is usually 4x, and is referred to as the <button class='glossary-text'>scanning objective</button>. The highest power is usually either 40x or 100x.

The 100x lens is an oil immersion lens and will not be used for this investigation. For the purpose of this activity, we will consider the 40x lens as the high power lens; this is often called the high power (or “high-dry”) objective. There is usually a single objective between the scanning and <button class='glossary-text'>high power objectives</button>, most commonly with a magnification of 10x. It is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>low power objective</button>. The objective used to view an object can be changed by rotating the revolving <button class='glossary-text'>nosepiece</button> located near the bottom of the tube above the stage. Most modern microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>parfocal</button>, which means that if the image is focused, it should remain in focus when you change the objective with minimal finetuning using the fine adjustment knob.

Depth of FieldIt is important to remember that the objects observed under a microscope are three-dimensional. An object may appear flat, especially after being pressed under a coverslip. However, when magnified, the depth of the material on the becomes more apparent. When you view an object and only part of it is in focus, you are observing the limits of the microscope’s , which refers to the thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus. Depth of field is shallower on high power than on low power. In other words, when you view an object under high power, less of it is in focus at one time than when the same object is viewed under low power. offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications.

pageData.question: Why do stereomicroscopes offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes?

options.text: They use lower magnifications.
They use higher magnifications.
They have “high-dry” objectives.
They have an oil immersion objective.
They have a dimmed light source.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Stereomicroscopes offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications.

pageData.question: Which of the following magnifications best describes the scanning objective?

options.text: 4x

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The lowest power is usually 4x and is referred to as the scanning objective.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Each objective magnifies objects to a different power. The lowest power is usually 4x; the highest power is usually either 40x or 100x. It is important to remember that the objects observed under a microscope are three-dimensional. An object may appear flat, especially after being pressed under a coverslip. However, when magnified, the depth of the material on the slide becomes more apparent. When you view an object and only part of it is in focus, you are observing the limits of the microscope’s depth of field, which refers to the thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus. Depth of field is shallower on high power than on low power. In other words, when you view an object under high power, less of it is in focus at one time than when the same object is viewed under low power. Stereomicroscopes offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Each objective magnifies objects to a different power. The lowest power is usually 4x; the highest power is usually either 40x or 100x. It is important to remember that the objects observed under a microscope are three-dimensional. An object may appear flat, especially after being pressed under a coverslip. However, when magnified, the depth of the material on the slide becomes more apparent. When you view an object and only part of it is in focus, you are observing the limits of the microscope’s depth of field, which refers to the thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus. Depth of field is shallower on high power than on low power. In other words, when you view an object under high power, less of it is in focus at one time than when the same object is viewed under low power. Stereomicroscopes offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications.

pageData.text: Calculating MagnificationAn object is magnified by both the and the lens of the microscope. To determine the total magnification, multiply the magnification power of the eyepiece (which is printed near the lens) by the magnification power of the objective lens being used to view the object.
Total Magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
For example, if human cheek cells are being viewed using the 40x objective lens with a microscope that has a 10x ocular lens, the total magnification of the cheek cells is 40 x 10 = 400x.

Greater magnification does not always produce better viewing. A clear, sharp 200x image is more useful than a blurry 600x image. As magnification increases, the amount of light entering the lens decreases. Therefore, objects viewed at higher power will appear darker and may not be as clear. By adjusting the <button class='glossary-text'>iris diaphragm</button>, you can increase or decrease the amount of light directed onto the <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>.

Basic Care and Handling of a Microscope and Microscope SlidesMicroscopes are expensive, delicate pieces of equipment. Follow the guidelines below to keep your microscope in the best possible condition.
  • Never touch the lenses of the microscope with your fingers.
  • Use only lens paper to clean the lenses since fibers in paper towels or toilet paper can scratch the glass.
  • When storing a microscope, rotate the so that it is on the lowest power objective.
  • Adjust the stage so that it is as close to the objective as possible.
  • Keep the microscope covered when not in use to keep dust away.
  • Transport a microscope by using one hand to hold the scope by the arm and the other hand to support the base.
  • Store microscope slides out of direct light to prevent stained specimens from fading.

pageData.question: Which of the following suggestions will keep a microscope slide in the best possible condition?

options.text: Keep it out of sunlight.
Leave it on the microscope stage when not in use.
Clean it with a very strong alcohol.
Disinfect it with bleach.
Blow on it before each use.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Store microscope slides out of direct light to prevent stained specimens from fading.

pageData.question: How should you carry the microscope?

options.text: Hold it by the arm with one hand and support the base with the other hand.
Hold it by the arm with one hand and carry the power cord with the other hand.
Hold it by the base with two hands.
Hold it by the nosepiece with one hand and support the base with the other hand.
Hold it by the arm tightly with two hands.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Transport a microscope by using one hand to hold the arm and the other hand to support the base.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Microscopes are expensive, delicate pieces of equipment. Never touch the lenses of the microscope with your fingers. Use only lens paper to clean the lenses since fibers in paper towels or toilet paper can scratch the glass. When storing a microscope, rotate the nosepiece so that it is on the lowest power objective. Keep the microscope covered when not in use to keep dust away. Microscope slides are also delicate. Store microscope slides out of direct light to prevent stained specimens from fading.

pageData.desc:
A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, learn the parts and functions of a microscope. In Activity 1, you will turn on the microscope, adjust the stage, and place a slide on the stage. Next, you will focus the slide using the coarse and fine adjustments, and adjust the strength of the light source. Finally, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications. 
In Activity 2, you will replace slides on the stage and bring the slide into focus. Next, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications, and sketch or photograph your observations. Then, you will calculate the total magnification at which the slide was observed. You will repeat this activity until 5 total slides have been observed.
pageData.altText:
A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, learn the parts and functions of a microscope. Next, you will focus the slide using the coarse and fine adjustments, and adjust the strength of the light source. Finally, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications. 
In Activity 2, you will replace slides on the stage and bring the slide into focus. Next, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications, and sketch or photograph your observations. Then, you will calculate the total magnification at which the slide was observed. You will repeat this activity until 5 total slides have been observed.

Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button> are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Why are stereomicroscopes often referred to as “dissecting microscopes”?

options.text: The large working distance makes them ideal for dissections.
Stereomicroscopes come apart easily.
They are ideal for viewing small objects.
Only a few specimens will fit under the stereomicroscope.
They usually have two eyepieces, giving them greater depth of field.

assestmentData.question: Which part of the microscope holds the slide or the specimen?

options.text: the stage
the body tube
the fine adjustment knob
the coarse adjustment knob
the condenser

assestmentData.question: Which objective is referred to as the “high power objective” in this investigation?
Which of the following is true about the relationship between depth of field and magnification?

options.text: When magnification increases, the depth of field decreases.
There is no relationship.
When magnification increases, the depth of field increases.
The depth of field is the average of the microscope’s objectives.
The depth of field of a microscope determines how much magnification it can achieve.

assestmentData.question: What is the function of the nosepiece?

options.text: It holds the objective lenses.
It secures the slide on the stage.
It is a source of light.
It is the lens you look through.
It holds the eyepiece.

assestmentData.question: Which of these practices for using, handling or storing a microscope and microscope slides is true?

options.text: Keep dust away from the microscope by covering it during storage.
Touch the objective lenses when you need to put them in focus.
Store the slides in bright sunlight to prevent mold growth.
Rotate the nosepiece to the highest objective before storing the microscope.
Transport the microscope by placing both hands under the base of the microscope.

assestmentData.question: What is the function of the microscope diaphragm?

options.text: It regulates the amount of light passing through the specimen.
It is a source of light.
It condenses light from the light source into a narrow beam.
It is used to focus the specimen.
It holds the objective lenses.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.

Obtain all listed needed materials from your kit. (Remember: When carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.) You may use these templates to organize your drawings for this investigation.

Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify the key parts on your scope based on <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1,</button> <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>, and the microscope mat. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
In Activity 1, you will learn how to use a microscope by experimenting with and adjusting all of the components of the microscope. You will use this understanding in Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100x) , identify it, but do not use it during this investigation.

pageData.text: When you are ready to view a microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>, illuminate the microscope by doing one of the following:

text: If your microscope has a light, turn on the power so that the light at the base of the microscope is illuminated.
If your microscope has a mirror instead of a light, adjust the mirror so that it reflects light from the room through the condenser lenses.

pageData.text: Caution: If your microscope has a mirror, do not reflect sunlight off the mirror. This can damage your eyes.
Lower the stage as far away from the objectives as possible.
Turn the <button class='glossary-text'>nosepiece</button> to the lowest power objective.
For this activity, you may select any slide in your kit. Hold the microscope slide so that the slide label is on the left.
Place the slide, with the label to the left, onto the microscope stage.
Secure the slide on the stage with the stage clips.

Center the slide on the stage so that the object to view is directly under the objective and light is shining through it. If your microscope has stage adjustment knobs, rotate them to move the slide side to side or back and forth as needed to bring the object into view through the <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>.
Look at the stage from eye level and use the coarse adjustment knob to bring the slide close to the objective without actually touching it.
While looking through the eyepiece(s), use the coarse adjustment knob to bring the object roughly into focus. Then use the fine adjustment knob to bring the object into sharp focus.

Note: If you wear corrective lenses, you may find it easier to focus the microscope without your glasses or contacts. If you struggle to focus the scope while wearing corrective lenses, try again without the lenses.
To adjust the amount of light shining on the object, use the <button class='glossary-text'>iris diaphragm</button> control beneath the stage.

With the object in focus and centered, switch the microscope to a higher objective. Then, use the fine adjustment knob to bring the object into focus. Do not use the coarse adjustment knob with higher objectives.
When you are finished viewing the slide, turn back to the lowest power objective and lower the stage completely. Then carefully remove the microscope slide.
Repeat this procedure to view all of the slides in Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will examine the prepared <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button> of the letter e, colored threads, cork, household dust, and a mite and a tick using the microscope. You will sketch or photograph the specimens and record the total magnification of each image.

The letter “e” <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button> is good for the first viewing experience because it allows you to practice focusing and positioning slides. Moreover, you will observe several optical effects produced by the microscope. A microscope’s <button class='glossary-text'>field of view</button> is the area of the circle that is visible when looking through the ocular lens. The diameter of the field decreases with an increase in magnification.

text: Before placing it on the stage, look at the letter “e” slide. Note the size and orientation of the “e” on the slide.

pageData.text: Note: Remember, the label should be on the left.

text: View the letter “e” using the low power lens as described in Activity 1.
Switch to the next highest . Draw the letter “e” as it appears through the . Calculate and record the total magnification in the drawing.

pageData.text: Total Magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)

text: Move the slide to the left on the stage. Notice the direction in which the “e” appears to move.
Move the slide to the right on the stage. Notice the direction in which the “e” appears to move.
Move the slide forward on the stage, and then backward. Notice the direction in which the “e” appears to be moving.

pageData.text: Viewing the colored threads will help you understand the relationship between focus and <button class='glossary-text'>depth of field</button>, which is the distance above and below an object that is in focus. It varies with different objectives and magnifications.

text: Pick up this slide and inspect the crossed threads.
View the slide under low power, and locate the area where the three threads intersect.
Switch to the medium power objective. Draw the intersection of the threads. Calculate and record the total magnification in the drawing. You may wish to use colored pencils for your drawing.
Use the fine adjustment knob to focus on the yellow thread instead of the intersection of the threads.
Without adjusting the focus, move the stage so that you are now looking at the red thread.
Adjust the focus to bring the red thread into focus.
Without adjusting the focus, look again at the edges of the yellow thread and determine whether it is still in focus.

pageData.text: Cork is derived from the bark (outer) tissue of the cork oak. In 1665, Robert Hooke first coined the word “cell” as he described the structure of the walls of a thin piece of cork. The walls reminded him of the walls of a honeycomb.

text: Observe the cross-section of cork under low power.
Adjust the focus to examine different layers of the cork. If necessary, adjust the <button class='glossary-text'>diaphragm</button> to get a more detailed look at the cork cells.
Switch to a higher power of magnification and observe the cork. Adjust the focus to see the various layers.
Draw the cork. Calculate and record the total magnification in the drawing.

pageData.text: Household dust may look boring to the naked eye, but it can prove to be quite interesting when viewed under a microscope. Sometimes forensic experts use dust as evidence in criminal investigations.

text: Observe the dust under low power. Focus on the larger objects that can be observed under low power.
Switch to a higher power of magnification and observe the smaller objects.
Draw the dust. Calculate and record the total magnification in the drawing.
Can you identify any of the particles on the slide? Do you see fibers from clothing or rugs? Do you see particles such as human hair, pet hair, or soil? Record your observations.

pageData.text: Tick and Mite

text: Place the tick and mite slide onto the microscope and focus on the tick under low power.

pageData.text: Note: The tick is the larger of the two organisms on the slide.

text: Draw the tick in as much detail as possible or photograph it as it appears through the eyepiece. Try to draw the tick to the same scale that you observe in the microscope. In the drawing record the lowest total magnification that was required for the tick to fill the field of view.
Locate the mite on the slide. Focus on the mite under low power.

Increase the magnification on the mite from medium power to high power. Draw the mite in as much detail as possible or photograph it as it appears through the eyepiece. In the drawing, record the lowest total magnification that was required for the mite to fill the field of view.
Return microscope slides to their storage box and place them with the kit.
Cover the microscope and store it for future use.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Questions
text: When the letter “e” slide was moved left, which direction did the “e” on the microscope slide appear to move? When the slide was moved away from you, which direction did the “e” appear to move?
When viewing the colored threads slide under high power, can you use the fine adjustment knob so that you can focus on all three threads simultaneously? Why or why not?
Cork can float on water. As you examine cork under the microscope, what features do you observe that might account for this characteristic?
Identify as many materials as you can in the dust slide. If you cannot identify a particular material, take a guess at what it might be.
Describe how you can quantify the size difference between the tick and the mite using the microscope.

Magnifies the specimen
Magnifies 4x the actual size Magnifies 10x the actual size Magnifies 40x the actual size
tableData.hoverText: Magnifies the specimen Magnifies 4x the actual size Magnifies 10x the actual size Magnifies 40x the actual size

tableData.text: Holds the microscope slide or specimen
Allows for controlled movement of the slide
Secures the slide on the stage
Condenses light from the light source into a narrow beam
Regulates the amount of light passing through the specimen
Source of light (usually an electric-powered light bulb)
Used first to focus the specimen; not used for the high power objective lens
Used to make minor adjustments in focusing; only adjustment used with high power objective lens

pageData.altText:
A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, learn the parts and functions of a microscope. In Activity 1, you will turn on the microscope, adjust the stage, and place a slide on the stage. Next, you will focus the slide using the coarse and fine adjustments, and adjust the strength of the light source. Finally, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications. 
In Activity 2, you will replace slides on the stage and bring the slide into focus. Next, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications, and sketch or photograph your observations. Then, you will calculate the total magnification at which the slide was observed. You will repeat this activity until 5 total slides have been observed.

pageData.content: How to care for the slides used with your microscope

data.title: Binocular
data.content: Describes a microscope with two eyepieces

data.title: Body tube
data.content: The long cylinder extending from the eyepiece

data.title: Compound light microscope
data.content: A type of microscope that uses two sets of lenses (a compound lens system) to obtain higher magnification than a stereomicroscope

data.title: Coverslip
data.content: A thin, protective piece of glass

data.title: Depth of field
data.content: The thickness of an area that can be viewed in focus

data.title: Eyepiece
data.content: The part of a microscope through which the user views a specimen or slide; it contains an ocular lens

data.title: Field of view
data.content: The the maximum area visible when looking through the ocular lens

data.title: High power objective
data.content: The high power lens, usually either 40x or 100x; also called the high-dry objective

data.title: (Iris) diaphragm
data.content: Regulates the amount of light directed onto the slide

data.title: Low power objective
data.content: The lens between the scanning and high power objectives, most commonly a magnification of 10x

data.title: Monocular
data.content: Describes a microscope with one eyepiece

data.title: Objective
data.content: A magnifying lens found at the opposite end of the of the body tube

data.title: Parfocal
data.content: The ability of a microscope to remain in focus when there is a change to the objective with minimal fine-tuning if the image is already in focus

data.title: Resolution
data.content: The ability of a microscope to distinguish between two adjacent objects

data.title: Slide
data.content: A small, rectangular piece of glass

data.title: Stereomicroscope
data.content: A type of microscope with a large working distance; also called a dissecting microscope

data.title: Working distance
data.content: The space between the lens and the specimen
